verses.verse: (Prov 9.8; 15.10) Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge, but those who hate to be rebuked are stupid.
(Prov 8.35) The good obtain favor from the LORD, but those who devise evil he condemns.
(Prov 10.25) No one finds security by wickedness, but the root of the righteous will never be moved.
(Prov 14.30; 31.23; 1 Cor 11.7) A good wife is the crown of her husband, but she who brings shame is like rottenness in his bones.
The thoughts of the righteous are just; the advice of the wicked is treacherous.
(Prov 1.11; 14.3) The words of the wicked are a deadly ambush, but the speech of the upright delivers them.
(Ps 37.36; Mt 7.24) The wicked are overthrown and are no more, but the house of the righteous will stand.
One is commended for good sense, but a perverse mind is despised.
Better to be despised and have produce (Cn: Heb servant) than to be self-important and lack food.
(Deut 25.4) The righteous know the needs of their animals, but the mercy of the wicked is cruel.
(Judg 9.4; Prov 28.19) Those who till their land will have plenty of food, but those who follow worthless pursuits have no sense.
The wicked covet the proceeds of wickedness, (Or covet the catch of the wicked) but the root of the righteous bears fruit.
(Prov 18.7; 2 Pet 2.9) The evil are ensnared by the transgression of their lips, but the righteous escape from trouble.
(Job 34.11; Prov 13.2; Isa 3.10, 11) From the fruit of the mouth one is filled with good things, and manual labor has its reward.
(Prov 14.12; Lk 18.11) Fools think their own way is right, but the wise listen to advice.
(Prov 29.11) Fools show their anger at once, but the prudent ignore an insult.
(Prov 14.5) Whoever speaks the truth gives honest evidence, but a false witness speaks deceitfully.
(Ps 57.4) Rash words are like sword thrusts, but the tongue of the wise brings healing.
(Ps 52.5) Truthful lips endure forever, but a lying tongue lasts only a moment.
(v 5) Deceit is in the mind of those who plan evil, but those who counsel peace have joy.
(Ps 91.10; Prov 14.14; 1 Pet 3.13) No harm happens to the righteous, but the wicked are filled with trouble.
(Prov 6.17; 11.20; Rev 22.15) Lying lips are an abomination to the LORD, but those who act faithfully are his delight.
(Prov 13.16; 15.2) One who is clever conceals knowledge, but the mind of a fool (Heb the heart of fools) broadcasts folly.
The hand of the diligent will rule, while the lazy will be put to forced labor.
(Prov 15.13; Isa 50.4) Anxiety weighs down the human heart, but a good word cheers it up.
The righteous are released from misfortune, (Syr: Meaning of Heb uncertain) but the way of the wicked leads them astray.
The lazy do not roast (Meaning of Heb uncertain) their game, but the diligent obtain precious wealth. (Meaning of Heb uncertain)
(Prov 11.19) In the path of righteousness there is life; in walking its path there is no death.
